Today is a special day for me and my family.  This afternoon I will have the privilege of being sworn in as the fifth U.S. Representative from the 19th District of Texas.  I consider this a sacred honor entrusted to me by God and the people of West Texas, and am committed to serving accordingly.   My family and I enter this solemn occasion with much gratitude and humility.  Please pray for the Lord’s wisdom, understanding and protection as we strive to uphold the constitution and values of District 19.

I am honored to be sworn in as only the 5th representative for the nineteenth district of Texas. I am also proud to have my loving family at my side as we kickoff the 115th Congress.     West Texas is a special place full of hardworking people with traditional values and a deep love for our families and country. As your Congressman, I will work daily to ensure our nation’s leaders understand the importance and uniqueness of our great region. Rural America needs a voice in Washington and America needs our rural communities!

Today, I had the distinct honor of becoming the first freshman Member of the 115th Congress to preside over the House Floor.  As I took the gavel, I was proud to hold the values and voices of the people of West Texas with me.

Israel is our steadfast ally and the only true democracy in the Middle East.  I am proud to stand with Israel through this resolution denouncing President Obama’s deplorable treatment of our longtime partner in freedom. I applaud my colleague, Congressman Ed Royce (CA-39), for his leadership.    Rest assured, I will continue to work tirelessly alongside our new administration to repair our partnership with Israel.

As part of The Great Compromise, the electoral college ensured that the American people throughout our united states would have balanced representation in the election process. The genius of our Founding Fathers was their ability to ensure every state played an equal role in ‘a more perfect union.’  Today, Congress confirmed the votes of the electoral college and Donald J. Trump as the next President of the United States. We are now one step closer to having a Republican held House, Senate, and White House. It’s now time to get to work and move our country in the direction that ‘We the People’ voted for on November 8th

On National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, I am proud to join eleven other newly-elected Members of Congress in signing a letter to President Obama urging him to light the White House blue to honor our public servants.

Folks in West Texas, like all hard-working Americans, rightfully expect to have their government balance its budget and live within its means.   I will begin working immediately to help forge a more efficient and accountable federal government – beginning with the repeal of one of its costliest and most disastrous laws: Obamacare.

West Texas is home to more than 14 million acres of farm and ranch land of all types, producing more cotton than any other region in the world. Our producers are feeding and clothing the world, creating thousands of jobs, and bringing millions in economic impact to our country.   Unfortunately, many in our country take that for granted. I am excited to serve alongside my fellow Texan, Mike Conaway as a champion for American agriculture.

I believe you can measure the character of a nation by the way they treat their veterans - we have a lot of character building to do in America.   I am committed to fighting for those who fought for our freedoms and restoring a culture of respect for all who wore the uniform.

Since Obamacare was implemented, 80 rural hospitals have closed and 600 more are in danger of closing.  I was proud to use my first House Floor speech to fight for the 60 million hard-working families living in small-town America.
I just officially cast my vote to begin repealing Obamacare...one step closer to restoring the greatness of America!

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was a childhood hero of mine. He was a man of great courage and conviction. He never let bitterness control him, but was driven by the love of God and his fellow man.  "We must live together as brothers or perish together as fools" - MLK
We have hit the ground running to ensure West Texas has a seat at the table in Washington. Sign up for our newsletter to stay up to date!
Wreck 'Em!   My dad played for the Texas Tech University Red Raiders in the 1950's alongside Gerald Myers.

Congratulations to former Governor Sonny Perdue on his nomination to lead the Agriculture Department! Like many of us in West Texas, former Governor Perdue grew up around farmland and the agriculture business.   In my new role on the Agriculture committee, I look forward to working alongside Mr. Perdue to fight for farmers, ranchers, and all good Americans who earn their living off of the land.

I wish all of my fellow West Texans could be here on this historic day. The American experiment in liberty and democracy lives on with a peaceful transition of power...BACK to ‘We the People’!   As President Trump said in his speech: "government exists to serve the people"...and in my new role as your Congressman, I exist to represent and serve the people of West Texas.

Our tax dollars should NOT be used to fund abortions. Every American - even those who cannot vote, speak, or defend themselves - has the same right to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.   This is an area where the Constitution, my constituents, and my convictions will not allow me to budge.
Proud to see Lubbock resident Jason White bring some West Texas civility to our nation’s capital. He is proof that conservatives are some of the most compassionate people in the land.

After congratulating President Donald J. Trump and introducing myself, I said, "Rural America is for you...please remember our farmers and ranchers."   He responded, "Don't worry...we will take care of them...we will take good care of them, don't you worry!"

As thousands of #ProLife Americans descend on Washington today for the The March for Life, nearly 150 of my colleagues and I sent a letter to President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Mike Pence outlining the ways we can work together to advance the rights of unborn children and their mothers.   We’re excited about the tremendous opportunity we have to work with the White House on implementing pro-life policies that protect our nation’s most vulnerable. Full letter here → goo.gl/hJbMPJ

My fellow West Texans -   Many of you have contacted me with questions about President Trump's executive order and I'd like to share with you where I stand.   Congress has been advised by top intelligence officials multiple times that terrorists are targeting our refugee program to infiltrate America. We have seen terrorists carry this out in other countries, including France, where at least two of the Paris attackers posed as refugees and went on to kill at least 130 people and wounded hundreds of others.   It is important that our commander in chief puts the safety of Americans first. Given concerns about the inadequate vetting of refugees and problems with our immigration system, this temporary pause is intended to ensure the safety of our citizens.   Our hearts go out to the refugees who have no agenda except to find a better life for their families, but we need to develop a process for identifying those who wish to do America harm while also finding the best way to support those who truly need our shelter.

In recent history, too many federal judges have sought to revise the Constitution rather than interpret it.  The recent nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court is the beginning of a shift from judicial activism to respect for the intent and integrity of the Constitution.  I truly believe the nomination of Judge Gorsuch represents a turning point in our nation's history, and one that will profoundly impact generations of Americans.

It is an honor to be selected for three subcommittees that will greatly impact agriculture policy and the lives of countless farmers and ranchers nationwide. Led by Chairman Mike Conaway, my colleagues and I will work daily to be a champion for the good Americans who earn their living by working the ground and stewarding God's green, gold, and even white (with cotton) earth!  You can learn more about my subcommittee assignments here ↓

As noted by the Founders -- in the plain language of our Constitution -- the federal government shall not infringe upon our right to keep and bear arms.  Today the House passed legislation I cosponsored that would strike down the Obama administration's last ditch effort to restrict the #SecondAmendment freedoms of nearly four million law-abiding citizens.   More info here → https://goo.gl/XTWDA4

Today we remember Lubbock legend Buddy Holly, often regarded as the artist who defined Rock & Roll.   A proud West Texan whose music impacted generations, his legacy will be remembered forever. #TheDayTheMusicDied

Please join me in wishing a very happy 100th birthday to Lubbock resident and World War II veteran, Bryan Hardin!  We owe a debt of gratitude to the men and women of the "Greatest Generation." They believed in duty, honor, and country - America is stronger because of their sacrifice.
Congrats to Danny Amendola and the New England Patriots! Leave it to a Texan and Red Raider to make the key play of the game. #WreckEm!

Happy Birthday, Mr. President!  Ronald Reagan was the President who inspired me to get involved in public service.  He knew what too many in our nation have forgotten: America's strength has always been in ‘We The People’!    In Congress, I will work daily to honor Reagan's legacy by restoring our respect for the Constitution, individual and states rights, and a limited federal government.

The Electronic Communications Privacy Act (ECPA) was written long before email became a part of Americans’ everyday lives and currently allows the government to access email that is 180 days old or older without a warrant.   Today I’m voting YES on legislation that will modernize our digital privacy laws and ensure that if the government wants access to your digital content, they must get a warrant first. Today the House took action to rein in federal control over education -- a top priority of mine. Here's how we're giving power back to parents, states and local education leaders:

Education is the key to success. In my first action as Chairman of the House Subcommittee on Economic Opportunity, I was proud to host a bipartisan roundtable focused on the success of our student veterans. Our subcommittee studied the graduation rates of veterans who used the G.I. Bill to achieve their goal of earning a degree.    Serving our nation's heroes should always be a bipartisan issue, and as Chairman, I will continue to lead the charge to ensure our veterans are receiving the tools they need to be successful.

Our first month here in Washington has been incredibly busy, productive, and encouraging. My team and I are burning the midnight oil to ensure the people of West Texas are heard in Congress.   Here’s a recap of our first month in just two minutes ↓
It has been a long journey thus far, but I remain as committed, excited, and honored to serve West Texas as I did on day one.  Be sure and sign up for my newsletter to stay up to date! ↓
We're working hard to rein in the federal government and return power back to you - the American people.  Click below to read an update on our progress! ↓

Texas landowners should not have to worry about the federal government coming in and taking away land that they have lawfully-owned and paid taxes on for years, especially when the government has not conducted a proper survey.   Today I’m supporting the Red River Gradient Boundary Survey Act to resolve the Bureau of Land Management’s egregious overreach and bring certainty to landowners along the Red River.

It was great to speak at the National Cotton Council of America Annual Meeting this weekend in Dallas! I would like to congratulate all members of the leadership boards within the Council. Thank you for your continued service, leadership and dedication to American agriculture and to the cotton industry. I look forward to working with you.

We are truly the land of the free BECAUSE of the brave. I was honored to be presented with the U.S. Army seal today by MG Malcolm Frost.   In Congress, I remain committed to fighting for those who risk their lives to defend our freedom.

Another insurer exits the market and reminds the American people of Obamacare’s abject failure. With less competition and less choice, the patient loses every time.   It’s time to increase competition, lower costs, and put YOU back in control of your healthcare.

The rural communities and small towns of TX-19 are critical to the success of our country. As we set the stage for the 2018 Farm Bill, it’s important that the House Agriculture Committee reviews the economic challenges facing our rural farmers and ranchers. It’s one of my main priorities to address the current challenges, and ensure the American producers aren’t put out of business by bad policy decisions.
Today we took action to ensure states aren’t forced to funnel taxpayer money to abortion providers. Glad to support this #ProLife legislation authored by my colleague, Diane Black.

It’s high time to break down the bureaucracy of the VA and give our veterans the care they deserve. Today I held my first hearing as Chairman of the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Economic Opportunity to examine why some employees at the VA spend 100% of their working days doing union activities while receiving tax-payer funded salaries, especially when the time employees spend on union activities rather than serving patients has resulted in a backlog of hundreds of thousands of veterans’ claims.   While this hearing today is not going to completely resolve all of the issues related to official time and union activities on the tax-payer’s dime, I think this discussion is necessary and pertinent as we continue to reform and fix the VA as a whole.

Thank you to all who made the 65th Annual Lubbock Lions Club Pancake Festival a huge success. Nearly 6,000 pounds of pancake mix were used to serve our community and support local charities...everything is bigger in Texas!
Happy Presidents' Day, and thank you to all who have served our nation from the Oval Office! From Lincoln to Reagan, the United States has been blessed by strong leaders who love our great country.
Glad to be back in Abilene today surrounded by some great West Texans! I ran into my friend, and former Congressman, Charlie Stenholm.

Congratulations to the Trinity Christian School boys on their big State Title win. West Texas is proud of your hard work!
Serving and supporting our veterans should always be a bipartisan issue.  Thank you to my fellow Texan, Congressman Beto O'Rourke, for joining me this morning.

Today, President Trump took action to protect the property rights of countless West Texans. By blocking the EPA’s Waters of the United States Rule, the Administration has made it clear that a massive federal expansion into state and local jurisdiction of our waters will not be permitted. I applaud this order and stand by our producers and so many others in welcoming the good news to farm country.
The most important thing about President Donald J. Trump is not how he delivers a speech...it's how he has already DELIVERED on many of the promises he made to the American people! #JointAddress

What resonates for me as a West Texan, is President Donald J. Trump's concept of the ‘forgotten man.’   Too many Americans feel like they've been left behind and gone unheard -- working and middle class families, small business owners, and rural America! #JointAddress
How are we going to "Make America Great Again"? We must return to the Constitutional and traditional American values that have made us strong. #JointAddress

Today I took to the House floor to echo the President’s charge, calling for bold leadership in repealing and replacing Obamacare. We have a new era that has dawned on American politics, and our citizens are demanding that we don’t conduct our business as usual. These are times that call for bold leadership and bold action.

One of my colleagues said it best when he described what is a military man or woman. He said, "it is someone who gave up their today so we could have our tomorrow.”   The service we provide our veterans pales in comparison to the sacrifice they made for our country. We must do everything in our power to change the culture of the VA and ensure our vets receive the care they have earned and deserve.

My fellow West Texans,  The facts are indisputable, President Obama's attempt to plan our healthcare economy from Washington has failed. I've spent nearly two years criss-crossing twenty-nine counties in West Texas, and I can report with certainty that no law or policy has been more reviled, more destructive, or more intrusive than Obamacare. It is crushing our small businesses and main-street Americans.  The American Health Care Act repeals Obamacare and is a step in the right direction to freeing the American people from the scourge of government controlled healthcare.   For the first time since the passage of Obamacare, the American Health Care Act will lower premiums by 10%, reduce the deficit by $337 billion, and make the biggest entitlement reform in generations – saving taxpayers $883 billion. This bill strikes at the heart of Obamacare by repealing its mandates, eliminating its taxes, and gutting its regulations.   Make no mistake, this legislation is not perfect, and I will continue to fight for more conservative and fiscally responsible policy outcomes. But, when the dust settles, and the debate is over, we cannot allow perfect policy aspirations to be the enemy of good, conservative results.   My constituents sent me to Washington to tackle the tough issues and solve big problems. I committed to them that I would repeal Obamacare, and I plan to keep that promise.

On March 16, 1909 the City of Lubbock, Texas was incorporated and became home to 1,938 West Texans. One hundred and eight years later, Lubbock is now home to over 240,000 folks, a tier one research university, a vibrant arts community, and fields white with cotton.   Happy 108th Birthday, Lubbock! I am proud to call this great city my home.

I want to assure the people of West Texas that I am fighting to make the Republican healthcare proposal better for the American people.   Today, during the House Budget Committee reconciliation markup, I urged my colleagues to consider changes that would further reform Medicaid, dismantle more of Obamacare’s taxes, and give back authority to the states. I promised to repeal Obamacare, and that’s what I am working to do.   We must implement work requirements for able-bodied adults without dependents to receive Medicaid benefits. It’s time to begin incentivizing hard work and personal responsibility if we want to defend our country’s limited resources. ↓

Democrats argued yesterday during our budget markup that the American Health Care Act would take money away from women’s health care services. Those assertions are absolutely false. Instead of funneling taxpayer dollars to abortion providers, the American Health Care Act would provide over $400 million in funding to community health centers.   To suggest the American Health Care Act harms women is a hollow argument and I am offended by some of these hyperbolic accusations from my colleagues on the other side of the aisle. The AHCA does the right thing by the American people by enforcing the current law -- and the public sentiment -- regarding funding for abortions. #PassTheBill

West Texas lost an art icon this month with the passing of Louise Hopkins Underwood. Mrs. Underwood was a mother of six and a pioneer in her quest to promote passion for the arts and a stronger sense of community on the South Plains.   Last week I honored her life and legacy on the House floor.

For seven years now, Republicans have promised the American people that if given control of the Presidency, the House and Senate, we would repeal and replace Obamacare. Today, with the majority of Republicans and the support of President Trump, I was prepared to fulfill that promise. I am disappointed that some of my colleagues were not able to reach consensus and reverse the destructive course of government-controlled healthcare that has wreaked havoc on our middle-class families and small businesses in West Texas.   I have always believed that there is no such thing as perfect legislation as long as you’re dealing with imperfect people and I’ve said all along this bill has room for improvement. I worked hard to get many of those improvements – like work requirements - included in the final bill. If we’re going to take advantage of our unified Republican leadership, deliver on our promises to the American people, and move our country in a conservative direction, we must learn how to govern and not let perfect be the enemy of good.      I remain committed to repealing Obamacare, and will work daily to get the job done.  As we move forward, I will continue fighting to secure our border, strengthen our economy, improve the farm bill, and promote the West Texas values that have made our country strong.

On National Medal of Honor Day, please join me in remembering and honoring those men and women who went above and beyond in their service to our country.   The freedom we enjoy is only possible because 'some gave all' to defend it.

I was honored to speak to their Saturday morning church service and see how they are bringing hope to our community at the Lubbock Dream Center.   These folks are making a huge impact on our city, and I am very proud of them!

Today I was honored to join President Donald J. Trump at the White House as he signed two bills I co-sponsored into law.  Both of these bills rein in the Federal Government to ensure our states, families, and teachers —not Washington—make the decisions on what is best for their students.

It is my strong belief that we cannot change the course of our country in any meaningful way without changing the culture of Washington. We need an environment that encourages politicians to do what is RIGHT- not for their party or special interests- but for their COUNTRY.   That is why I am proud to fight for TERM LIMITS in Congress. We need to go BIG, we need to go BOLD, or we need to go HOME.

The great state of Texas produces nearly 20% of the nation’s beef cattle. I’m proud to be a voice for our cattlemen in Congress as they work to feed the American people and I look forward to being a champion for them as a member of the Congressional Beef Caucus. Internet privacy has always been regulated by the Federal Trade Commission and NOT the Federal Communications Commission. That's why every Texas Republican in the House as well as Senators Cruz and Cornyn voted to repeal this midnight Obama administration rule.

You can read it here: http://politi.co/2pARFbj  Regardless, many are concerned that states will utilize waivers to deny coverage for preexisting conditions. Again, under the American Health Care Act, you can NOT be denied coverage based on a preexisting condition, and you can NOT be charged higher based on a preexisting condition so long as you keep continuous coverage. 16 years ago today, the world as we knew it changed.  For me, as for most Americans, the images of September 11, 2001 remain seared in my memory. As a young man serving in the White House for President George W. Bush, I vividly recall the emotions of that day – first shock as I watched the two planes fly into the World Trade Center, then outrage when it became clear it was a terrorist attack, and, ultimately, profound grief for the victims and those who lost loved ones on that day.  There was no alarm; just people frantically telling us to get out fearing another plane would crash into the White House at any moment. As I got into my truck, I could see the smoke billowing from the Pentagon and jets scrambling above. Driving away, I watched people streaming out of buildings, gathering on sidewalks, and desperately trying to call their families to no avail. It was an eerie and surreal moment I’ll never forget.  For those who lost loved ones, the grief and heartache remain to this day. Not since Pearl Harbor have Americans experienced and collectively witnessed such death and destruction on our homeland. This was a defining moment for our country; one that would, like other major challenges throughout our history, try our spirits and test our resolve.  When we heard the voicemail recordings from passengers on United Flight 93, we were reminded once again that Americans are a special breed of people. Laying down their lives, the passengers on that flight refused to be paralyzed by fear and took matters into their own hands. “Let’s Roll!” became a rallying cry for our country to help lift up the families and friends of those lost, the brave first-responders who rushed headlong into danger, and all affected on that terrible day.  In the days that followed, Americans once again proved our resilience. In countless acts of selflessness, people from all walks of life pulled together to restore a great American city and comfort a broken and grieving nation. We heard a strong and compassionate Commander in Chief, who embodied America’s resolve as he stood on the rubble of the World Trade Center and declared, “I can hear you, the rest of the world can hear you, and the people who knocked down these buildings will hear all of us soon!” Perhaps more than anything, we witnessed a oneness in our country too often divided by our differences.  On that day, we were not defined by race or gender, urban or rural, Republican or Democrat, Main Street or Wall Street; we were Americans. As Americans, we don’t always agree on what is best for our country, but 9/11 is a reminder that the ties that hold our democracy together are stronger than any force that seeks to divide us.    In the wake of the Hurricane Harvey disaster, and now Hurricane Irma, we see again the very best of the American spirit where neighbors are sacrificing for neighbors without regard to ideology or color.  The blessing of such trying times is this – we discover what we’re really made of, and we’re reminded, once again, what really matters.  That may be a common human experience, but no other people collectively reflect it like Americans.

Eighty rural hospitals have closed their doors since 2010, including 19 permanently or temporarily in the state of Texas. Without access to basic medical services, communities in America’s breadbasket and energy basin would not survive. That’s why I’ve introduced the Healthcare Enhancement for America’s Rural Towns (HEART) Act.   This legislation extends two programs vital to the sustainability of rural hospitals and the communities they serve – the Low-Volume Adjustment Program and the Medicare Dependent Hospital Program.   By extending the Medicare Low-Volume Adjustment Program for two years and, for the first time, permanently extending the Medicare Dependent Hospital Program, we can provide the assurance and continuity that our rural hospitals desperately need in order to serve our communities in the future. And just as importantly, we do this in a way that’s budget-neutral, without spending any additional taxpayer monies.

Last night, the House passed bipartisan, common-sense legislation I authored that would ensure service-disabled veterans are provided with the best in-home adaptation services to assist with their needs, and at a reduced cost to taxpayers.   Currently, disabled veterans who need special modifications to their homes, such as wheelchair ramps, are stuck in a broken system with long wait times and costly services. My bill would transfer responsibility for home adaptations from the Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) program to Specially Adapted Housing agents, a part of the VA that has the knowledge, experience, and capacity to speed up these construction projects, more efficiently serve our disabled veterans, and save taxpayers money.   Our veterans, especially our disabled veterans, deserve the best services that VA can provide, and this bill is another step towards doing just that.

In the transition from deployment to employment, apprenticeship programs have proven to be extremely successful. Roughly 20,000 veterans are actively training or participating in these programs and their employment outcomes are nothing short of impressive.   According to VA’s data, over 90 percent of veteran apprentices are employed after completing their programs, with an average starting wage of over $60,000! These programs aren’t just a win for our veterans, they are a win for the taxpayer. Every dollar invested in apprenticeship programs sees a return in benefits of $35!   While it’s clear to see the advantages of apprenticeship programs, like in many parts of the VA, this program is hampered by needless burden and bureaucracy. Currently, private employers who offer these programs in more than one state have to register with each state individually. Burdened by the difficulty and trail of paperwork that this creates, many employers only choose to participate in a limited way, or to just not offer them altogether.   Today, the House passed the Veteran Apprenticeship and Labor Opportunity Reform or the VALOR Act, authored by my good friend and colleague, Rep. Ro Khanna. This bill will streamline the registration process for employers, which in turn encourages them to participate and leads to more opportunities for our veterans.    Given the tremendous sacrifice our veterans have made for our country, we should do everything we can to ensure they have access to good jobs and the VALOR Act does just that.

Merry Christmas from our family to yours...and happy birthday to the greatest man who ever lived!  “Here is a man who was born in an obscure village, the child of a peasant woman. He grew up in another village. He worked in a carpenter shop until He was thirty. Then for three years He was an itinerant preacher.  "He never owned a home. He never wrote a book. He never held an office. He never had a family. He never went to college. He never put His foot inside a big city. He never traveled two hundred miles from the place He was born. He never did one of the things that usually accompany greatness. He had no credentials but Himself...  "While still a young man, the tide of popular opinion turned against him. His friends ran away. One of them denied Him. He was turned over to His enemies. He went through the mockery of a trial. He was nailed upon a cross between two thieves. While He was dying His executioners gambled for the only piece of property He had on earth – His coat. When He was dead, He was laid in a borrowed grave through the pity of a friend.  "Nineteen long centuries have come and gone, and today He is a centerpiece of the human race and leader of the column of progress.  "I am far within the mark when I say that all the armies that ever marched, all the navies that were ever built; all the parliaments that ever sat and all the kings that ever reigned, put together, have not affected the life of man upon this earth as powerfully as has that one solitary life.”   - Dr. James Allen Francis
